title: Foundation Era
intro: Singapore's digital journey began in 1991 when the National University of Singapore (NUS) set up Technet with financial backing from the National Science and Technology Board (NSTB). At that point, internet access was limited to research and development use only. This foundation set the stage for Singapore's transition to commercial internet services three years later.

milestones.detail: National University of Singapore sets up Technet with NSTB funding, giving Singapore its first internet connection — restricted to academic and R&D use only.
milestones.image_alt: NUS Central Library, Kent Ridge Campus

milestones.detail: Singapore Telecom launches SingNet, marking the start of commercial internet access for the public, alongside a dial-up email service.
The former TechNet network is acquired and relaunched as Pacific Internet, Singapore's second ISP, increasing competition and consumer choice.
milestones.image_alt: Vintage dial-up modem representing the era of early ISP competition

milestones.detail: A third ISP, Cyberway, enters the market. That same year Singapore's IT2000 masterplan set out the vision to develop Singapore into an 'intelligent island' with an advanced nationwide information infrastructure interconnecting computers in nearly every home, school, and workplace.
milestones.image_alt: Singapore skyline, symbolic of the IT2000 intelligent island vision

milestones.detail: Singapore transitions from slow dial-up connections to Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL) broadband, dramatically improving speeds and reliability for homes and businesses.

sources.citation: Tan, J., and Wong, S. "The Internet as a Learning Tool: Planning Perspectives (the Singapore Experience)." Internet Society, 12 Mar. 2000.
"History of Internet in Singapore: From Academic Link to 5G Digital Future." GovTech Singapore, 12 Aug. 2021.
Choo, Chun Wei. "IT2000: Singapore's Vision of an Intelligent Island." Intelligent Environments, edited by Peter Droege, North-Holland, 1997, pp. 49–65.
